messages.subject: Re: Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: ... left with substantial holes after removing the rust. Hi, trying to get caught up, and probably violating the five minute rule.  Be that as it may, let me
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...> wrote:
> If there is very bad rust pitting, it's possible that you will be
left with substantial holes after removing the rust.

Hi, trying to get caught up, and probably violating the five minute
rule. Be that as it may, let me interject two self-learned Chicken
truths about rust:

1. It's always worse than it looks. If there is ANY surface
discoloration (red, black, gray, even white), then there is pitting.
More a problem, of course, on blades as opposed to tsuba. But any
rusting of any kind means more than just finger stones on blades to
correct the damage. I have not the experience on kodogu to say
something even semi-intelligent, but suspect that if any discoloration
is removed, the surface will not be as smooth as when first made,
unless considerable nearby unrusted metal is removed as well.

2. When there is scabby red/brown rust on blades, the pitting is kinda
bad to extremely bad, and it's difficult to impossible to tell simply
by looking which it is. This Chicken truism comes from polishing
("Forgive me, God, for I have sinned") two Pacific Era gunto with
equivalent scabby surface rust. Paradoxically, on the the traditional
tamahagane (no stamps) gunto, the rust pits went to China, in depth
they were as long or longer than their width. I couldn't get out all
the pitting without grinding away over three hundred years worth of
metal, and had ot give up with about five percent of the pits
remaining. On the non-traditional, Seki-stamped gunto (Kumemune
mentioned a while ago), though the surface rust was essentially
identical, the pits were no where near as deep, and, as it turned out,
not deeper than the waves in the crap wartime polish, and so were not
the major concern in the end.

Bottom line, rust is either bad, or extremely bad, and it's tough to
tell between the two before getting serious. FWIW, JMO.

NC ;o)

Jim Gilbert wrote:
> Rich,
> I tend to agree with Alan. Looking at the front of the guard it does appear to be Edo period and indeterminate style. I suspect that what you're seeing in the rim may be the structure of the forge welding brought out by the rust. It's not unusual to see pronounced layering in, for example, Akasaka guards that have been badly rusted. Seeing a sharp ridge like that would be unusual for tekkotsu. Also tekkotsu are usually smoother, darker and more lustrous than the surrounding iron (although not always so with Kanayama).
>
> I do however have a Kanayama tsuba that I think is quite old that has a somewhat similar look in the rim. I've never been able to decide how much of the appearance is due to how it was made vs. how it might have rusted. Next time I set up to take macro photos I'll get some images of the rim for comparison. The face of that guard also looks quite old and in Kanayama style, though.

messages.subject: Re: Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: ... Owari ... Shimizu ... Katchushi ... to ... centimeter ... the ... of ... mistakes. ... very interesting.... note the tsuba pics I posted, there are few
messages.messageBody:
>
> "Masters like shodai and nidai Yamakichibei, Nobuie and Hoan of
Owari
> had
> studied the workmanship of old Owari and Kanayama tsuba, whose iron
> has the
> 0.6-0.8% of carbon which produces tekkotsu. Nevertheless certain
> schools
> demanded higher standards, among them Yagyu; the Hayashi and
Shimizu
> groups in
> Higo; and Nobuie, Hoan and Yamakichibei of Owari; while the
Katchushi
> group such
> as Myochin used traditional forging methods.
>
> "Forging to produce the jitetsu and that for tekkotsu should be
> carried out
> separately. Each tsuba-ko decides the proportion of tekkotsu metal
to
> use, for
> example 1-5% of that for of jitetsu. This is cut into one
centimeter
> pieces,
> 4-5 mm thick, which are mixed with the jitetsu during forging. If
the
> forging
> is not good enough, it can open up later when heated in the process
of
> tekusarakashi, which results in cracks or so called forging
mistakes.
> Interestingly enough most of the highly valued futoji-mei Nobuie
> tsuba show
> those cracks.
>
>
very interesting....
note the tsuba pics I posted, there are few " cracks/openings " on
the flat surface of the rim filled in with copper/gold. I always
wonder if they are " intentional ".

milt

messages.msgSnippet: Milt and Rich, This seems to have started when Yahoo changed the photo file structure from folders to albums.  The global privilege settings have not changed,
messages.messageBody:
Milt and Rich,

This seems to have started when Yahoo changed the photo file structure from folders to albums. The global privilege settings have not changed, so you're supposed to be able to post photos. Here's something to try -- create a new album and try to put your photos in there. I'm guessing that the problem may be happening when you try to update an old folder that has been converted to the new format.

I haven't had a problem putting photos in newly created albums, but haven't tried uploading anything to an old one. Rich also has moderator privileges on this list, so he should be able to do whatever I can, other than delete the whole thing.
Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, I tend to agree with Alan.  Looking at the front of the guard it does appear to be Edo period and indeterminate style.  I suspect that what you re seeing
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
I tend to agree with Alan. Looking at the front of the guard it does appear to be Edo period and indeterminate style. I suspect that what you're seeing in the rim may be the structure of the forge welding brought out by the rust. It's not unusual to see pronounced layering in, for example, Akasaka guards that have been badly rusted. Seeing a sharp ridge like that would be unusual for tekkotsu. Also tekkotsu are usually smoother, darker and more lustrous than the surrounding iron (although not always so with Kanayama).

I do however have a Kanayama tsuba that I think is quite old that has a somewhat similar look in the rim. I've never been able to decide how much of the appearance is due to how it was made vs. how it might have rusted. Next time I set up to take macro photos I'll get some images of the rim for comparison. The face of that guard also looks quite old and in Kanayama style, though.

Jim



Hi Alan, it may be a little pitted in the mimi but they are bones, and
too big I think for edo, though not necessarily so I guess.

Cheer

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, If there is very bad rust pitting, it s possible that you will be left with substantial holes after removing the rust.  This guard though is in good
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
If there is very bad rust pitting, it's possible that you will be left with substantial holes after removing the rust. This guard though is in good condition and it's very doubtful that there would have been extreme rust in only a few spots on the rim.

That said, tekkotsu are generally more rust resistant than the surrounding iron, so in the case of a very rusty guard the tekkotsu may become pronounced. I don't know if that is what you've experienced.

Jim


jim,
I look very closely at pic #3..............
I have seen this type very often in my " accumulation " of iron sukashi
tsuba. I always thought they are what's left after one clean off the rust.

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: earlier-period smithing, not smiting.  Don t be so quick to agree with the spell checker... Occasionally Edo period Shoami work will be carved to simulate
messages.messageBody:
"earlier-period smithing," not smiting. Don't be so quick to agree with the spell checker...

Occasionally Edo period Shoami work will be carved to simulate tekkotsu and other features of earlier-period smiting.

Jim


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: Barry, I would have posted photos sooner if I had known.  In general, yes, tekkotsu are a good thing, at least for Owari region work.  I can t think of a case
messages.messageBody:
Barry,
I would have posted photos sooner if I had known. In general, yes, tekkotsu are a good thing, at least for Owari region work. I can't think of a case where it would indicate poor quality. It's part of what separates the better Owari, Kanayama, etc., work from the routine products.

The mid to late Muromachi period is prime time for tekkotsu and they continue to a lesser degree in Momoyama. Early Edo period Yagyu, Ono and sometimes Akasaka will also show them, although not in quite the same way as Muromachi period Owari sukashi or Kanayama. In general they are not seen in Edo period work. Norisuke and other late Edo copies of Yamakichibei, Kanayama, Nobuie, etc., will show tekkotsu, but they generally look forced and artificial, often oversized and overdone. Of course sometimes maybe they got it right too, and we're still being fooled by those pieces.

Occasionally Edo period Shoami work will be carved to simulate tekkotsu and other features of earlier-period smiting.

Jim



Jim,

BRILLIANT - one picture is truly worth a thousand words, let alone five! I
don't believe I have ever seen this in real life, so after 40 years collecting
blades and only occasionally finding tsuba I can now look out for tekkotsu
"seriously". A couple of questions spring to mind:

- Is tekkotsu limited to a "time window"?? That is, is it only found in certain
iron tsuba (sukashi??) from say (hahaha) 1500 to 1620?? I guess most Edo iron
tsuba don't have tekkotsu.

- Is tekkotsu when found a "good" indicator???

Thanks for great pics.

Best regards,
Barry Thomas.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: Ken, Good, glad it helped.  I plan to update the photos on my site and will include images of rims where there is something to see.  Given storage and
messages.messageBody:
Ken,
Good, glad it helped. I plan to update the photos on my site and will include images of rims where there is something to see. Given storage and bandwidth limitations I will probably have to get rid of the pieces that I don't have any longer so that I can focus on the best examples.

The technical aspects of tekkotsu are far from settled. The quote that Pete posted from the Solingen catalog is an interesting one. I don't know whether that is how tekkotsu were formed in the Muromachi period. I have read hypotheses crediting everything from the source of the ore onward for being the cause of tekkotsu. There is even an idea that the bones were not even visible in the original piece but are only revealed over time due to the corrosion and/or wear resistance of the higher carbon regions. I doubt that that's entirely true, but it is a factor for guards with condition problems -- the tekkotsu will stand out.

Jim



Jim,

Excellent, while of course I would love to handle
them, these pictures are the next best thing. Great
stuff and makes it clearer. If someone had the time,
it would be great to put these up on your/someone's
website. All these sites devoted to swords, could use
some more to tsuba. Would love to see tekkotsu
website depicting various schools.

Now for the next question- why so different? metal
used? folding techniques? when forming the mimi what
steps would they do (I know big questions)?

Thanks- as always you are extremely helpful.
Ken
\

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: It looks like Edo period Kyo-sukashi in poor shape with a pitted mimi. Alan ... From: Richard Turner To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Sent: Tuesday, March 14,
messages.messageBody:
It looks like Edo period Kyo-sukashi in poor shape with a pitted mimi.
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, March 14, 2006 10:38 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei


Nice Jim, good work. These are excellent photo's and an invaluable help.
If I may, how would you classify this ?.

The condition is down a bit ( as are the photo's sorry ). I bought it as
Muromachi Owari, then got it and thought it might be Kanayama. There is
a long large ( rope ) bone in the mimi, and quite a few smaller normal
bumpy bones. There are also small bones in the hira, running around the
mimi. I have not been able to pin the theme either, besides the ginger
leaves.

Any clues appreciated.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/owari-hira.jpg

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/owari-mimi.jpg


best wishes

Rich

messages.subject: Re: Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: I am taking the liberty of posting a reply from Jim I copied awhile back on the board about tekotsu: Checking the Yagyu article in the European NBTHK
messages.messageBody:
I am taking the liberty of posting a reply from Jim I copied awhile
back on the board about tekotsu:

'Checking the Yagyu article in the European NBTHK "Selected Fine
Swords..." book
I found these interesting comments':

"Masters like shodai and nidai Yamakichibei, Nobuie and Hoan of Owari
had
studied the workmanship of old Owari and Kanayama tsuba, whose iron
has the
0.6-0.8% of carbon which produces tekkotsu. Nevertheless certain
schools
demanded higher standards, among them Yagyu; the Hayashi and Shimizu
groups in
Higo; and Nobuie, Hoan and Yamakichibei of Owari; while the Katchushi
group such
as Myochin used traditional forging methods.

"Forging to produce the jitetsu and that for tekkotsu should be
carried out
separately. Each tsuba-ko decides the proportion of tekkotsu metal to
use, for
example 1-5% of that for of jitetsu. This is cut into one centimeter
pieces,
4-5 mm thick, which are mixed with the jitetsu during forging. If the
forging
is not good enough, it can open up later when heated in the process of
tekusarakashi, which results in cracks or so called forging mistakes.
Interestingly enough most of the highly valued futoji-mei Nobuie
tsuba show
those cracks.

The bibliography cites an article "A Brief Summary of Tekkotsu" in
Token Bijutsu
#522, July 2000, 9-11 by a tsubako named Kazunari Naruki. I'm
guessing that
this is the source for the above comments.

Jim

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

leaves.

Any clues appreciated.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/owari-hira.jpg

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/owari-mimi.jpg


best wishes

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, BRILLIANT - one picture is truly worth a thousand words, let alone five!  I don t believe I have ever seen this in real life, so after 40 years collecting
messages.messageBody:
Jim,

BRILLIANT - one picture is truly worth a thousand words, let alone five! I
don't believe I have ever seen this in real life, so after 40 years collecting
blades and only occasionally finding tsuba I can now look out for tekkotsu
"seriously". A couple of questions spring to mind:

- Is tekkotsu limited to a "time window"?? That is, is it only found in certain
iron tsuba (sukashi??) from say (hahaha) 1500 to 1620?? I guess most Edo iron
tsuba don't have tekkotsu.

- Is tekkotsu when found a "good" indicator???

Thanks for great pics.

Best regards,
Barry Thomas.


----- Original Message -----
From: "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, March 15, 2006 3:27 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei


Ken,
I photographed some Kanayama tekkotsu and posted them here:

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/d4b0

Hopefully it will make things more rather than less clear. It's difficult to
capture the whole package in a few photos.

JIm

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, Excellent, while of course I would love to handle them,  these pictures are the next best thing.  Great stuff and makes it clearer.  If someone had the
messages.messageBody:
Jim,

Excellent, while of course I would love to handle
them, these pictures are the next best thing. Great
stuff and makes it clearer. If someone had the time,
it would be great to put these up on your/someone's
website. All these sites devoted to swords, could use
some more to tsuba. Would love to see tekkotsu
website depicting various schools.

Now for the next question- why so different? metal
used? folding techniques? when forming the mimi what
steps would they do (I know big questions)?

Thanks- as always you are extremely helpful.
Ken

Jim,

While I am reading kantei #2 and becoming familiar
with the groups people are talking about, you didn't
give me a chance to ask a question back on #1. Is it
possible to get picture of the tekkotsu from kanayama
for comparison? I am visual, there is a dirty joke in
there, and that would really help sink it into the
brain.

Very interesting all of this. I have lots of books I
just purchased and several months of reading. Just
have to finish the sword section of the boston museum
and I'm into 4 or 5 tsuba books. Hopefully, I can
start to get a handle on some of this. So I wouldn't
even begin to give an answer.

Thanks again.
Ken

messages.messageBody:
Jim,

While I am reading kantei #2 and becoming familiar
with the groups people are talking about, you didn't
give me a chance to ask a question back on #1. Is it
possible to get picture of the tekkotsu from kanayama
for comparison? I am visual, there is a dirty joke in
there, and that would really help sink it into the
brain.

Very interesting all of this. I have lots of books I
just purchased and several months of reading. Just
have to finish the sword section of the boston museum
and I'm into 4 or 5 tsuba books. Hopefully, I can
start to get a handle on some of this. So I wouldn't
even begin to give an answer.

Thanks again.
Ken

--- Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wrote:

> The scan of the front of the guard does not do it
> justice, but is sufficient to see what's there. The
> photos of the mimi give some sense of the tekkotsu
> that place the guard in the Owari region. Given the
> shape of the rim and the design, the two most likely
> choices are Kanayama and Owari sukashi. I think
> either answer is acceptable given that you are
> working from pictures.
>
> The thickness and somewhat squared rim lean toward
> Kanayama, but can also be seen in Owari work. The
> guard is on the thick end of the spectrum for either
> type. The diameter is possible for either group,
> although on the large side for Kanayama. The style
> of the tekkotsu is the most important point.
> Kanayama tekkotsu tend to form pronounced, sometimes
> rough bumps. Owari tekkotsu are low, smooth and
> emerge from the plate with more subtlety, forming
> "bean" shaped and "rope" forms. This guard shows
> both of these latter types. Also, Kanayama guards
> will often show some tekkotsu on the face, but Owari
> guards do not.
>
> Wild goose designs are common in Owari work. It's
> not impossible to imagine a design like this in a
> Kanayama guard, but it is more naturalistic,
> complicated and even a little delicate for that
> group. The majority of the evidence points toward
> Owari sukashi.
>
> The guard is in very good condition, so it may look
> younger than it is. The quality of the iron and the
> tekkotsu are unlikely to date to the early Edo
> period, and are consistent with pieces from mid to
> late Muromachi. The birds at the top and bottom of
> the sukashi design seem too free spirited to be from
> that time, though and seem more like Momoyama.
> Given that design is easier to manipulate than iron,
> I lean toward late Muromachi, but Momoyama is
> possible.
>
> The guard has a kanteisho to Owari from the NBTHK.
> No date given.
>
> Yagyu is in the correct region, but the texture of
> the metal will be cloudy/sandy and will tend to show
> many linear laminations in the rim. It is also not
> a Yagyu design.
>
> I included this tsuba in the Akasaka display at
> Tampa to show the likely Owari origins of the
> Akasaka group. While some Ko-Akasaka guards will
> show tekkotsu, they are not of this type and the
> color and texture of the iron is different. The rim
> would show a more rounded shape in Akasaka. The
> cutting of the sukashi would have sharper edges.
> The design does have a bit of Akasaka feeling, but
> there would probably be more asymmetry and
> abstraction in an Akasaka piece.
>
> That's all I can think of at the moment. Any other
> observations or questions?
>
> Jim
>
>
>
> OK, here is a guard for kantei:
>
>
>
http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/2964?c
>
> 77.0 mm H x 74.8 mm W, 7.2 mm thick at the mimi
> and 7.1 mm thick at the seppa dai.
>
>
> As far as I know it has not been published, but it
> has been exhibited at a couple of study meetings.
> So, if you've already seen it and remember the
> attribution, please don't post the answer to the
> list. It is mumei and there are two almost equally
> reasonable attributions, but I think that there is
> more evidence for one than the other.
>
> Respond with your bid on or off list as you
> prefer.
>
> Jim
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been
> removed]
>
>

Behalf Of Jim Gilbert
Sent: Wednesday, March 08, 2006 3:44 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei

Gordon,
Agreed -- note that I said: "The quality of the iron and the tekkotsu are
unlikely to date to the early Edo period, and are consistent with pieces
from mid to late Muromachi."

I have a new kantei piece read to go.

Jim



Hi Jim,

Thank you for the fun kantei. I refrained to participate, but I might add,
and I am pretty sure you are aware of this thinking, with Owari, tekkotsu
of
the type exhibited in your piece would prevent most Japanese collectors
from
considering anything but late Muromachi for the tsuba and not Momoyama or
early Edo. The same holds true for Kanayama. It is also interesting that
some large Owari sukashi looking pieces have been attributed to Kanayama,
no
doubt based on the stylistic differences you pointed out.

Finally, the link you gave is still to the Owari piece. Do you put up a
new
kantei piece?

Gordon

the type exhibited in your piece would prevent most Japanese collectors from

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim, Thank you for the fun kantei. I refrained to participate, but I might add, and I am pretty sure you are aware of this thinking, with Owari, tekkotsu of
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim,

Thank you for the fun kantei. I refrained to participate, but I might add,
and I am pretty sure you are aware of this thinking, with Owari, tekkotsu of
the type exhibited in your piece would prevent most Japanese collectors from
considering anything but late Muromachi for the tsuba and not Momoyama or
early Edo. The same holds true for Kanayama. It is also interesting that
some large Owari sukashi looking pieces have been attributed to Kanayama, no
doubt based on the stylistic differences you pointed out.

Finally, the link you gave is still to the Owari piece. Do you put up a new
kantei piece?

Gordon

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Jim Gilbert
Sent: Tuesday, March 07, 2006 12:44 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei

The scan of the front of the guard does not do it justice, but is sufficient
to see what's there. The photos of the mimi give some sense of the tekkotsu
that place the guard in the Owari region. Given the shape of the rim and
the design, the two most likely choices are Kanayama and Owari sukashi. I
think either answer is acceptable given that you are working from pictures.

The thickness and somewhat squared rim lean toward Kanayama, but can also be
seen in Owari work. The guard is on the thick end of the spectrum for
either type. The diameter is possible for either group, although on the
large side for Kanayama. The style of the tekkotsu is the most important
point. Kanayama tekkotsu tend to form pronounced, sometimes rough bumps.
Owari tekkotsu are low, smooth and emerge from the plate with more subtlety,
forming "bean" shaped and "rope" forms. This guard shows both of these
latter types. Also, Kanayama guards will often show some tekkotsu on the
face, but Owari guards do not.

Wild goose designs are common in Owari work. It's not impossible to imagine
a design like this in a Kanayama guard, but it is more naturalistic,
complicated and even a little delicate for that group. The majority of the
evidence points toward Owari sukashi.

The guard is in very good condition, so it may look younger than it is. The
quality of the iron and the tekkotsu are unlikely to date to the early Edo
period, and are consistent with pieces from mid to late Muromachi. The
birds at the top and bottom of the sukashi design seem too free spirited to
be from that time, though and seem more like Momoyama. Given that design is
easier to manipulate than iron, I lean toward late Muromachi, but Momoyama
is possible.

The guard has a kanteisho to Owari from the NBTHK. No date given.

Yagyu is in the correct region, but the texture of the metal will be
cloudy/sandy and will tend to show many linear laminations in the rim. It
is also not a Yagyu design.

I included this tsuba in the Akasaka display at Tampa to show the likely
Owari origins of the Akasaka group. While some Ko-Akasaka guards will show
tekkotsu, they are not of this type and the color and texture of the iron is
different. The rim would show a more rounded shape in Akasaka. The cutting
of the sukashi would have sharper edges. The design does have a bit of
Akasaka feeling, but there would probably be more asymmetry and abstraction
in an Akasaka piece.

That's all I can think of at the moment. Any other observations or
questions?

Jim



OK, here is a guard for kantei:

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/2964?c

77.0 mm H x 74.8 mm W, 7.2 mm thick at the mimi and 7.1 mm thick at the
seppa dai.


As far as I know it has not been published, but it has been exhibited at a
couple of study meetings. So, if you've already seen it and remember the
attribution, please don't post the answer to the list. It is mumei and
there are two almost equally reasonable attributions, but I think that there
is more evidence for one than the other.

Respond with your bid on or off list as you prefer.

Jim


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]




Yahoo! Groups Links

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: My getting it right, Rich, was really the result of familiarity with test protocols: Go for the less obvious answer, rather than great tsuba wisdom, I m
messages.messageBody:
My getting it right, Rich, was really the result of familiarity with test protocols: "Go for the less obvious answer," rather than great tsuba wisdom, I'm afraid. And the more I looked at the seppa dai's size, the more I thought "It's really Kanayama, after all."

David


----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, March 06, 2006 2:34 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei setsumei


Thanks Jim, excellent work. I enjoyed that very much though I was not
really correct. Well Done David and all who may have made bid privately
that got it right.

The cross overs that can occur in works form the same area can make it
difficult sometimes to pick the true source of the item, this being the
case with this Owari guard. I thought after I placed my bid it was
probably verging on the wrong end of the large side for Kanayama but it
was too late :-)

I hope we see more of these in the future and more participation from
the group here.

Thank you Kim for an excellent effort, it was a of of fun.

warm regards

Richard

messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Jim!  I think that was a great exercise and would certainly like to see more of that on a continuing basis.  I remembered this guard from Tampa and so
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Jim! I think that was a great exercise and would certainly like to
see more of that on a continuing basis. I remembered this guard from Tampa and

Jurgis


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Kantei setsumei
messages.msgSnippet: The scan of the front of the guard does not do it justice, but is sufficient to see what s there.  The photos of the mimi give some sense of the tekkotsu that
messages.messageBody:
The scan of the front of the guard does not do it justice, but is sufficient to see what's there. The photos of the mimi give some sense of the tekkotsu that place the guard in the Owari region. Given the shape of the rim and the design, the two most likely choices are Kanayama and Owari sukashi. I think either answer is acceptable given that you are working from pictures.

The thickness and somewhat squared rim lean toward Kanayama, but can also be seen in Owari work. The guard is on the thick end of the spectrum for either type. The diameter is possible for either group, although on the large side for Kanayama. The style of the tekkotsu is the most important point. Kanayama tekkotsu tend to form pronounced, sometimes rough bumps. Owari tekkotsu are low, smooth and emerge from the plate with more subtlety, forming "bean" shaped and "rope" forms. This guard shows both of these latter types. Also, Kanayama guards will often show some tekkotsu on the face, but Owari guards do not.

Wild goose designs are common in Owari work. It's not impossible to imagine a design like this in a Kanayama guard, but it is more naturalistic, complicated and even a little delicate for that group. The majority of the evidence points toward Owari sukashi.

The guard is in very good condition, so it may look younger than it is. The quality of the iron and the tekkotsu are unlikely to date to the early Edo period, and are consistent with pieces from mid to late Muromachi. The birds at the top and bottom of the sukashi design seem too free spirited to be from that time, though and seem more like Momoyama. Given that design is easier to manipulate than iron, I lean toward late Muromachi, but Momoyama is possible.

The guard has a kanteisho to Owari from the NBTHK. No date given.

Yagyu is in the correct region, but the texture of the metal will be cloudy/sandy and will tend to show many linear laminations in the rim. It is also not a Yagyu design.

I included this tsuba in the Akasaka display at Tampa to show the likely Owari origins of the Akasaka group. While some Ko-Akasaka guards will show tekkotsu, they are not of this type and the color and texture of the iron is different. The rim would show a more rounded shape in Akasaka. The cutting of the sukashi would have sharper edges. The design does have a bit of Akasaka feeling, but there would probably be more asymmetry and abstraction in an Akasaka piece.

That's all I can think of at the moment. Any other observations or questions?

Jim

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/2964?c

77.0 mm H x 74.8 mm W, 7.2 mm thick at the mimi and 7.1 mm thick at the seppa dai.


As far as I know it has not been published, but it has been exhibited at a couple of study meetings. So, if you've already seen it and remember the attribution, please don't post the answer to the list. It is mumei and there are two almost equally reasonable attributions, but I think that there is more evidence for one than the other.

Respond with your bid on or off list as you prefer.

Jim
